Award.AwardTitle: Control of Mixing Driven by Coalescence of Sessile Drops

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will address issues of sessile droplet coalescence, such as what role does asymmetries in bulk fluid properties, contact angle, and drop size have on mixing in two drops coalescing on a surface, and what different effects could occur when the surfaces are either homogeneous or heterogeneous. The work will use a testing platform, in which specimen drop and satellite drops of reagent are allowed to mix. The research plan is organized into three Objectives. In the first the PIs aim to investigate the effects of properties, contact angle and size on coalescence in homogeneous surfaces. The second objective will consider interfacial tension asymmetry, and the third will examine coalescence in more interesting surfaces, including superhydrophobic substrates.

This proposal has a strong, clearly developed research plan that, if successful, can have a technologically broad impact since many applications such as spray coating and inkjet printing rely on the coalescence of drops on surfaces. Control over these mixing patterns during coalescence can lead to new applications that take advantage of this control including medical diagnostic platform based on the merging of a central target specimen drop with several satellite drops containing reagents. The proposal also includes educational broad impact through developing and teaching new graduate-level courses, supervising students, and outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to control the location and extent of internal mixing of fluids during coalescence of sessile droplets. The objectives of the proposed work were to: (1) quantify the impact of asymmetries in bulk fluid properties, drop volume, and contact angle on mixing in two drops of fluid coalescing on a homogeneous surface, (2) quantify the role of interfacial tension asymmetries on mixing, and (3) control contact line mobility and use heterogeneous surfaces to dictate contact line location/mobility and thus control the location and volume of the mixing zone. Over the course of this grant period, we have accomplished some of these goals and also found numerous applications of compound droplets with ultralow interfacial tension and asymmetric properties. Products of this work include the publication of 5 archival journal papers, 11 conference presentations, 6 invited seminars and talks, and the training of 5 graduate students.

The intellectual merit of the proposed work resides in its potential to provide a broader understanding of the fluid flows and surface interactions that occur during the merging and mixing of two interacting miscible or immiscible phases. Through this work we have elucidated critical mechanisms controlling a broader set of interfacial flow applications, enabling greater control over key processes. There are several outcomes of the work conducted with the support of this grant: (1) observations of mixing and stability of interfaces between both miscible and immiscible interfaces in a variety of situations provide guidelines for control of the contacting of multiple fluid phases; (2) dehydration of microscale droplets containing phase separating polymers can be used as a rapid tool for analysis of phase coexistence curves, and ultralow interfacial tensions of these immiscible aqueous phases; (3) nanoliter trains of droplets can be used to vary composition at high resolution and measure partition coefficient of high value nanomaterials as a function of composition.   

The results of this work will have broad technological impact. Many applications rely on the coalescence among liquid drops on solid surfaces or in confined geometries, including spray coating and inkjet printing. The new tools we have developed for examining phase separation, partitioning, and slow mixing at interfaces with ultralow interfacial tension are valuable beyond the scope of this project for synthesis and manufacturing of nanoscale materials as well as for development of integrated on-chip analysis strategies.  The interfacial flows characterized by this work will have broad educational impact by providing highly visual images and fluid dynamics examples that have been incorporated into the major outreach, undergraduate research, and course development activities of the two PIs.
